title: Mixed feelings on first day back at school
summary: Pupils in Hong Kong had mixed feelings about returning to school, with some excited to see friends and others wishing for a longer holiday. Education Secretary Christine Choi emphasized mental health support, with over 420 schools signing up for the 4Rs Mental Health Charter. Choi also mentioned ongoing mental health programs in some schools and plans to encourage more participation. The bureau also sent advisory letters to help a primary pupil, absent for over two years, return to school.
description:
Hong Kong pupils on Monday had mixed feelings about going back to school, with some happy to see their old friends again and others saying they wished the summer holiday was longer. 

"I slept at around 9.30 last night because I was playing with my dad. [I miss the holiday] because I still want to play," said one pupil studying at a Tin Shui Wai school. 

Another pupil said she was nervous because there would be many new faces in class. 

Education Secretary Christine Choi wished pupils a good start to the academic year, and highlighted the need for mental health support.

Choi said as of July, more than 420 schools had signed up for the government's 4Rs Mental Health Charter. 

The 4Rs stand for rest, relaxation, relationship and resilience, and the charter is designed to address the plight of students struggling with their mental well-being. 

"I know some schools have their own mental health support programmes for students in progress or in future," she told reporters at a secondary school in Tuen Mun.

"I believe that as those plans are gradually integrated, more and more schools will participate in the 4Rs mental health charter, to encourage students to rest and relax, improve their resilience, and establish good interpersonal relationships."

Separately, the minister said her bureau has sent six advisory letters to follow up on a primary pupil who has reportedly been absent from school for more than two years.  

Choi said the bureau hopes to help the pupil get back to school as soon as possible by getting in touch with different stakeholders.

title: Standby Signal Number One could be issued on Tuesday
summary: Tropical Cyclone Yagi is intensifying, expected to issue Standby Signal No.1 between Tuesday afternoon and night. It will approach 800 km from Hong Kong on Tuesday, potentially affecting southern China. The observatory predicts Yagi to move towards Guangdong and Hainan Island, further intensifying, and may become a typhoon by Thursday.
description:
The observatory on Monday said it might issue the Standby Signal No.1 between Tuesday afternoon and Tuesday night, with Tropical Cyclone Yagi intensifying into a severe tropical storm. 

It said Yagi would be within 800 kilometres of Hong Kong on Tuesday and then edge close to the coast of southern China. 

It added there was a high chance Yagi would move towards the vicinity of the western part of Guangdong and Hainan Island and would further intensify. 

Looking ahead, the observatory forecast Yagi could strengthen to a typhoon by Thursday.

title: HK stocks fall as investors await Fed rate cut
summary: Hang Seng Index decreased 0.7%, to 17,862.59, due to US investors shifting from tech stocks to rate-cut sensitive shares, anticipating the Federal Reserve's expected rate cut on Sept 17-18. Hong Kong dollar may also see cuts due to US dollar peg.
description:
The Hang Seng Index fell 126.48 points, or 0.7 percent, to open at 17,862.59 points on Monday.

This comes as investors in the US have reportedly been switching from tech stocks, following results from tech giant Nvidia, into shares more likely to benefit from this month's expected interest rate cut.

The US central bank, the Federal Reserve, is expected to kick off a rate-cutting cycle at its monetary policy meeting on September 17-18. 

With the Hong Kong dollar pegged to the US dollar, any interest cut in the US should also lead to cuts in the SAR. (with additional reporting from Xinhua and Reuters)
